page.title: 17FARMING IN BISHOP BURTON
page.content: The landscape around Bishop Burton, formed on Wolds chalk, is open and undulating. Fields are traditionally large, hedges are few and shelterbelts cluster around farm buildings and in-bye land. In our block, the farms are large, mainly{arable holdings with one {livestock enterprise (usually pigs or {sheep or less commonly, dairy).}Grange Farm has a beef unit alongside its arable production, while Hill Farm produces pigs as a secondary concern. Sheep farming, a traditional Wolds industry has declined as farmers found more profit in converting suitable grazing to arable crops. The main crops are wheat and barley, with the necessary rotational break crops being the relatively new and profitable{oilseed rape and vining {peas.}Some sugarbeet is grown.
